text: Airplanes stay in the sky because their wings are shaped to create a difference in air pressure. As air moves faster over the curved top of the wing than beneath it, lift is generated, allowing the aircraft to overcome gravity.
Every single day, humanity sends over 300 million tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere — an invisible blanket that continues to trap heat around the planet.
A jet engine works by compressing incoming air, mixing it with fuel, igniting the mixture, and expelling the exhaust at extremely high speed — producing thrust through Newton’s third law of motion.
Steel is incredibly strong — but under the right conditions, even it can bend. When temperatures rise high enough, the metal softens, losing the rigidity engineers depend on.
More than one million children are hospitalized each year due to air pollution — a crisis most people never even see.
First, the rocket ignites. Then it accelerates through the lower atmosphere. Finally, once it reaches orbital velocity, it stops falling back to Earth and begins circling the planet.
The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean on Earth, covering more than 30% of the planet’s surface.
Only 3% of Earth’s water is fresh — and most of that is locked away in glaciers.
Electric vehicles reduce emissions, improve urban air quality, lower long-term fuel costs, and require less mechanical maintenance than traditional combustion cars.
For families living near active war zones, the sound of aircraft overhead is not a symbol of travel — but of fear.
A billion ants live in a single large colony.
The James Webb Space Telescope can detect light that has traveled for over 13 billion years, allowing us to see some of the earliest galaxies ever formed.
A cheetah can accelerate from zero to sixty miles per hour in just three seconds — faster than most sports cars.
Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy by exciting electrons inside chlorophyll molecules, initiating a chain of reactions that ultimately produce glucose.
Scientists estimate there are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the beaches on Earth combined.
